questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with long-standing hindfoot arthritis and severe pain refractory to conservative measures is scheduled for a triple arthrodesis. Which of the following joints will not be fused?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Triple arthrodesis fuses the hindfoot joints - subtalar, calcaneocuboid, and talonavicular - to relieve pain, stabilize the foot, and correct deformities.
  • The tibiotalar (ankle) joint is spared to maintain dorsiflexion and plantarflexion essential for gait mechanics.
  • Preserving the ankle joint ensures overall lower limb function is not compromised while addressing hindfoot pathology.

Triple Arthrodesis

  • Triple arthrodesis is a surgical procedure done in order to relieve pain in the rear part of the foot, improve stability of the foot, and in some cases correct deformity of the foot, by fusing of the three main joints of the hindfoot:
    • Calcaneocuboid joint: This joint is one of the three fused in triple arthrodesis to stabilize the lateral column. (Option A)
    • Talonavicular joint: This medial column joint is included in the fusion to correct deformity and provide midfoot stability. (Option C)
    • Subtalar joint: This joint is fused to eliminate painful inversion and eversion motion in the hindfoot. (Option D)
  • Always remember that the tibio talar (ankle joint) is not fused in triple arthrodesis.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with foot pain after landing on his foot improperly while playing basketball last night. His X-ray is shown here. What is the correct diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • A Jones fracture is a transverse break at the proximal metaphyseal - diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal, about 1.5 cm distal to the tuberosity, where blood supply is tenuous, leading to higher nonunion rates.
  • It commonly occurs with acute inversion or axial loading injuries in athletes, matching the mechanism of landing improperly during basketball.
  • Recognizing a true Jones fracture is critical, as it often necessitates non-weight-bearing immobilization or surgical fixation in active individuals to prevent delayed healing.

Explanation of Other Options:

March fracture (Option A): Stress fracture of the shafts of the 2nd - 4th metatarsals from repetitive loading, not an acute proximal fifth metatarsal injury.

Aviator fracture (Option C): Fracture of the talar neck caused by forced dorsiflexion, unrelated to the fifth metatarsal.

Lover's fracture (Option D): Calcaneal fracture from axial load in falls, affecting the heel bone rather than the metatarsal.

questions.text: Identify fracture name?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Pseudo Jones Fracture
    • It is an avulsion fracture of 5th metatarsal styloid reaching to the articular surface. This fracture can get displaced due to the pull of peroneus brevis tendon.
    • The fracture line extends into the tarsometatarsal joint but spares the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction, distinguishing it from a true Jones fracture.
    • Clinical management typically involves weight-bearing as tolerated in a stiff-soled shoe, since blood supply and healing potential remain favorable.

Explanation of Other Options:

Jones fracture (Option B): Fracture at the metaphyseal-diaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal, extending into the intermetatarsal joint and prone to nonunion.

Rolando fracture (Option C): A comminuted T- or Y-shaped fracture at the base of the first metacarpal (hand), not the fifth metatarsal.

Cotton fracture (Option D): Trimalleolar ankle fracture involving the medial, lateral, and posterior malleoli, unrelated to the foot's metatarsals.

questions.text: Identify the test name shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The Thomas test evaluates hip extension by flexing the opposite hip and observing if the tested thigh lifts off the table, indicating a fixed flexion deformity at the hip.

Thomas test is used to assess a fixed flexion deformity of the hip joint.

  • With the patient positioned flat on the bed, place a hand below their lumbar spine with your palm facing upwards (this helps to prevent the patient from masking a fixed flexion deformity by increasing lumbar lordosis).
  • Passively flex the hip of the unaffected leg as far as you are able to and observe the contralateral limb.
  • Repeat the assessment on the contralateral hip.

Interpretation: The test is positive (abnormal) if the affected thigh raises off the bed, indicating a loss of the hip joint extension. This would suggest a fixed flexion deformity in the affected hip.

questions.text: A patient with fracture of femur shaft develops petechiae, respiratory distress and decreased sPO2, 3 days after injury. What in the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Fat embolism syndrome typically occurs 24-72 hours after long-bone fractures, when marrow fat droplets enter the venous circulation, causing microvascular occlusion and inflammation.
  • It is often caused by physical trauma such as fracture of long bone, soft tissue trauma and burns.
  • Clinical Features: Triad of respiratory distress, CNS symptoms and Petechial rash.
  • Other features include tachycardia, tachypnea, increased temperature, hypoxemia (decreased sPO2), hypercapnea, thrombocytopenia.
  • Pathognomonic sign: Petechial rash on the upper anterior portion of the body, including the chest, neck, upper arm, axilla, shoulder, oral mucosa and conjunctivae.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypostatic pneumonia (Option A): Usually seen in elderly and debilitated patients; results from infection developing in the dependent portions of the lungs due to decreased ventilation of those areas, with resulting failure to drain bronchial secretions.

Haemolytic anemia (Option B): Involves red-cell destruction with jaundice and anemia, without respiratory distress or petechial rash in the post-traumatic setting.

Crush syndrome (Option C): Compression of extremities causes muscle swelling and neurological disturbances; characterized by major shock and renal failure after a crushing injury to skeletal muscle, but lacks the pathognomonic petechial rash and hypoxemia seen in fat embolism.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male sustained a fracture in his right knee as shown in the figure. What would be the treatment of choice in this fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The x-ray shows a displaced transverse fracture of patella, which is treated using tension band wiring.
  • Tension band wiring converts tensile forces on knee flexion into compressive forces at the fracture site, promoting stable fixation and healing.
  • This method allows early knee mobilization and preserves extensor function, leading to better functional outcomes.
  • Patella fractures are managed based on the fracture pattern.
    • Undisplaced fractures - cylinder cast.
    • Displaced transverse fractures - tension band wiring.
    • Comminuted fractures - patellectomy.
  • Osteochondral fracture

Explanation of Other Options:

Patellectomy (Option A): Reserved for comminuted patellar fractures where reconstruction is not possible; not indicated for simple transverse fractures.

Cylinder cast (Option C): Used only for undisplaced patellar fractures with maintained alignment; inadequate for displaced fractures needing surgical fixation.

Excision of small fragment (Option D): Employed in osteochondral fractures to remove loose fragments; not appropriate for larger displaced transverse fractures.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male soccer player twisted his knee during a rapid pivot and now complains of instability and pain. On examination, he has a positive Lachman test with excessive anterior tibial movement. Which of the following movements does the anterior cruciate ligament normally prevent?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The primary function of the Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) is to prevent anterior translation of tibia with respect to femur.
  • ACL takes origin from medial wall of lateral femoral condyle (posteriorly in the area of the inter-condylar notch) and courses anteriorly and medially to insert on the inter-condylar area of the tibia.
  • The ACL is critically important because it prevents the tibia from being pushed too far anterior relative to the femur. It is often torn during twisting or hyperextension injuries of the knee.
  • ACL tear is treated with ACL reconstruction. ACL reconstruction is most commonly done using autograft, meaning, the tissue used for repair is taken from the patient's body itself. The two most common sources for tissue are the patellar tendon and hamstrings tendon.
  • The posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) stretches from medial condyle of femur to the posterior intercondylar area.
  • This ligament prevents posterior displacement of the tibia relative to the femur.

questions.text: A 30 years old marathon runner presents with persistent pain over the dorsum of the foot on weight bearing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

March fractures are stress injuries of the metatarsals, most commonly the second and third, caused by repetitive microtrauma during weight-bearing activities; this matches the runner's presentation of dorsal foot pain on exertion.

March/Stress fracture

  • March fractures are metatarsal fractures, most commonly second and third metatarsal fractures caused by an overuse injury. The repetitive impact to the metatarsals with weight-bearing exercises cause micro fractures, which consolidate to form stress fractures.
  • The most common location of metatarsal stress fractures is the second metatarsal neck.
  • High-risk populations include runners, military recruits, ballet dancers, basketball players, or those with a recent increase in activity or training.
  • Distal second metatarsal stress fractures are the most common due to the high bending and shear forces. Further risk factors include a long 2nd metatarsal, hypermobile first ray, and women. Radiographs may be negative or show callus formation.
  • Advanced imaging of a bone scan or MRI can be obtained to confirm the diagnosis in cases of negative radiographs.
  • Initial treatment usually involves activity modification with a gradual return to sport over 6-8 weeks when asymptomatic.
  • Use of a walking boot, cast, or limiting weight-bearing can be used in patients whose symptoms don't resolve with activity modification or cannot comply with the recommendations.

Explanation of Other Options:

Morton's neuroma (Option A) causes burning or tingling between the toes, aggravated by forefoot compression, not dorsal midfoot pain.

Plantar fasciitis (Option B) presents with heel pain on the plantar surface, especially with first steps in the morning, not dorsum discomfort.

Interior talofibular ligament sprain (Option D) results from inversion injury with lateral ankle pain and instability, not midfoot stress pain in runners.

questions.text: Identify the angle shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Bohler's angle is measured on a lateral calcaneal radiograph by drawing one line from the highest point of the anterior process to the highest point of the posterior facet, and a second from the posterior facet peak to the superior tuberosity. Normally ranging 20-40°, it reflects calcaneal height and articular congruity.

Bohler's angle and angle of Gissane are used for the evaluation of calcaneum fractures.

They are evaluated on a lateral radiograph of calcaneum.

  • Bohler's angle:
    • Angle between line from highest point of anterior process to highest point of posterior facet + line tangential to superior edge of tuberosity
    • Normal 20-40°
    • Decreases in calcaneal fractures
  • Angle of Gissane:
    • Angle between line along lateral margin of posterior facet + line anterior to beak of calcaneus
    • Normal 120-145°
    • Increases in calcaneal fractures

questions.text: Jumper's fracture is seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Suicidal jumper's fracture is a transverse or H/U-shaped fracture of the upper sacrum (usually S1-S2) resulting from vertical axial loading when a patient falls from height.
  • The fracture pattern characteristically spares the anterior pelvic ring and appears as bilateral vertical fractures connected by a transverse line on lateral sacral or pelvic radiographs.
  • These injuries carry a high risk of cauda equina and sacral nerve root involvement; prompt recognition and surgical stabilization are crucial to prevent long-term neurological deficits.

Explanation of Other Options:

Calcaneum (Option A): Axial load injuries to the heel bone produce calcaneal fractures, but these are not termed jumper's fractures.

Tibia (Option B): Tibial shaft or plateau fractures occur with direct or indirect trauma, unrelated to the sacral H/U-shaped pattern of a jumper's fracture.

Neck of femur (Option D): Femoral neck fractures occur in low-energy falls (elderly) or high-energy trauma, but lack the characteristic sacral fracture configuration.

questions.text: Schatzker classification is used for?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The Schatzker classification categorizes proximal tibial (plateau) fractures into six types based on fracture morphology and energy mechanism, which aids in surgical planning and prognosis.
  • Accurate identification of the Schatzker type on radiographs or CT guides the choice of fixation technique, approach (medial vs. lateral), and postoperative weight-bearing protocol.
  • Higher types (IV-VI) reflect greater articular and metaphyseal involvement, often necessitating more complex fixation and prolonged rehabilitation.

choices.text: Stress fracture of the distal fibula 3-8 cm above lateral malleolus
Avulsion fracture of medial femoral condyle at the origin of the medial collateral ligament
Lateral tibial plateau avulsion fracture with anterior cruciate ligament tear
Salter-Harris Type III fracture of distal tibia

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Tillaux fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Tillaux-Chaput fracture: Avulsion of the anterior inferior tibio-fibular ligament from the anterior tibial margin (tibial counter-part of the Le-fort fracture). This is a Salter Harris type III injury. This is seen in adolescents and rare in adults.

  • It results from external rotation or eversion forces that exploit the asymmetric closure of the distal tibial physis - medial to lateral - leaving the anterolateral corner vulnerable.
  • Management hinges on displacement: nondisplaced fractures are treated in a cast, whereas >2 mm displacement requires open reduction and internal fixation to restore articular congruity and prevent growth arrest.

Explanation of Other Options:

Stress fracture of the distal fibula (Option A) is caused by repetitive loading in runners, presents as cortical microfractures without epiphyseal involvement.

Avulsion fracture of the medial femoral condyle (Option B) involves the distal femur at the MCL origin, unrelated to the distal tibial physis.

Lateral tibial plateau avulsion fracture (Option C) occurs with ACL injuries at the tibial plateau, not an epiphyseal injury of the distal tibia.

questions.text: Match the named fractures in Column A with their correct descriptions in Column B, then select the appropriate matching set.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Some commonly named fractures:

questions.text: A 42-year-old man falls from a two-metre height, landing on both heels. He presents with severe heel pain, swelling, and inability to bear weight. A lateral radiograph of the foot shows a decreased Bohler's angle. Fracture of which bone is most consistent with this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Decreased Bohler's angle is seen in fractures of calcaneum.
  • Bohler's angle is measured on a lateral calcaneal radiograph by drawing one line from the highest point of the anterior process to the highest point of the posterior facet, and a second from the posterior facet peak to the superior edge of the tuberosity
  • Normal 20-40°
  • In calcaneal fractures, impaction and collapse of the posterior facet reduce this angle, with values below 20° indicating increased comminution and loss of calcaneal height.
  • Restoration of Bohler's angle via surgical reduction and fixation correlates with improved subtalar joint alignment, heel height, and functional outcome.

Explanation of Other Options:

Naviculum (Option B): The navicular lies in the medial midfoot; Bohler's angle assesses calcaneal height and is not used for navicular fractures.

Cuboid (Option C): Cuboid fractures involve the lateral column of the midfoot and do not alter the posterior facet height of the calcaneum.

Talus (Option D): Talar fractures affect the tibiotalar and subtalar articulations but do not change Bohler's angle on lateral calcaneal films.

Key Takeaways:

  • A reduced Bohler's angle (<20°) on lateral radiographs is a hallmark of calcaneal fractures and reflects posterior facet collapse.

questions.text: A 23-year-old basketball player lands awkwardly on an inverted foot and presents with lateral ankle pain, swelling, and point tenderness over the lateral ligaments. Which ligament is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) runs from the lateral malleolus to the talus and is the primary restraint against inversion when the foot is plantarflexed.
  • Inversion sprains with plantarflexion place maximum stress on the ATFL, making it the most frequently torn lateral ankle ligament.
  • Injury to the ATFL accounts for approximately 80% of all ankle sprains and, if inadequately rehabilitated, can lead to chronic instability.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anterior tibiofibular ligament (Option A): Injured in high ("syndesmotic") ankle sprains from external rotation, not the typical inversion mechanism.

Posterior tibiofibular ligament (Option B): Part of the syndesmosis; injury occurs with high ankle sprains and is far less common in simple inversion injuries.

Calcaneofibular ligament (Option C): Second most commonly injured ligament in lateral sprains, usually involved with the ATFL but less likely to tear in isolation.

questions.text: For the fixation strategy shown in above image, fracture union is likely to proceed by what mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Secondary (indirect) fracture healing occurs when rigid fixation is absent, as with cast immobilization, intramedullary nailing, or bridge plating, leading to callus formation that unites the fracture.
  • There are 2 types of bone healing - primary and secondary.
    • Primary Fracture Healing or Direct Fracture Healing (Healing without Callus)
      • It is less common mode of fracture healing. It is seen in rigid internal fixation of fractures (compression plating) and in unicortical fractures (Greenstick fracture).
      • Cutting cones play a part in fracture healing here.
  • Secondary Fracture Healing or Indirect Fracture Healing (Healing by Callus Formation)
    • This is more common method of fracture healing. It is seen in absence of rigid fixation, where there is (cast immobilization, intramedullary nailing and bridge plating for comminuted metaphyseal fractures).
  • It is divided into five phases
    • Hematoma organizes by 2-3 days
    • Granulation tissue is fully formed by 2-3 weeks.
    • Provisional callus/Soft callus is seen first around 3 weeks.
    • Woven bone/Hard callus is seen by 3 months or bone consolidates (clinical union) by 3 weeks.
    • Remodelling continues to occur over 2-3 years.

questions.text: 60 years old man with diabetes mellitus presents with painless swollen right ankle joint. Radiograph of ankle joint shows destroyed joint with large number of loose bodies. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Charcot joint, also known as a neuropathic joint or Charcot (neuro/osteo) arthropathy, refers to a progressive degenerative/destructive joint disorder in patients with reduced / absent pain sensation and proprioception.
  • The most common cause is diabetes.
  • Most patients present with a limp, difficulty putting on shoes, or soft tissue swelling. But the clinching point is the absence of pain even in the presence of severe deformity and disability.
  • The characteristic physical findings are anesthetic or hypoesthetic feet (100% of patients), bony deformities (69% of patients), and soft tissue swelling (17% of patients). Many patients also have ulceration and abnormal callus formation.
  • The most common bony deformities are abnormal projections on the plantar arch (rocker sole) or other unusual prominence of the dorsal or medial arches of the midfoot or the MTP joint.
  • Treatment is difficult. Bracing is usually advised for some joints. CROW (charcot resistant orthotic walker) is now used for charcot's joint of foot and ankle.

Explanation of Other Options:

Clutton's joint (Option B): Symmetrical, painless knee effusions in congenital syphilis; does not involve destructive ankle changes or loose bodies.

Osteoarthritis (Option C): Degenerative joint disease with joint-space narrowing, osteophytes, and subchondral sclerosis; typically painful and lacks massive fragmentation or loose bodies of neuropathic arthropathy.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D): Inflammatory polyarthritis with pain, synovial proliferation, and marginal erosions; not characterised by painless joint destruction with debris.

questions.text: 64 years old female complaint of bilateral knee pain, pain increases while going up and down stairs. X-ray shows bilateral reduced joint space, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease most commonly seen in older adults. It worsens with activities that load the joint such as stair climbing or cross-leg sitting.
  • In the knee, progressive loss of articular cartilage leads to narrowing of the joint space, osteophyte formation, subchondral sclerosis, and cysts-features that correlate with pain during weight-bearing activities such as stair climbing.
  • Management focuses on activity modification, physiotherapy, analgesics, and, in advanced cases, joint replacement to restore function and relieve pain.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) presents with inflammatory synovitis, juxta-articular osteopenia, and erosions in younger patients, rather than isolated degenerative narrowing in an elderly individual.

Hemophilic arthropathy (Option C) is characterized by recurrent hemarthroses leading to synovial hypertrophy and joint destruction, typically with swelling and history of bleeding disorders.

Ankylosing spondylitis (Option D) is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy affecting young males with sacroiliac and spinal involvement; knee joint osteitis is uncommon.

choices.text: Fracture dislocation through tarso metatarsal joints
Fracture dislocation through inter metatarsal joints.

questions.text: What is Lisfranc fracture dislocation?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • A Lisfranc dislocation or injury describes a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot.
  • The Lisfranc joint is comprised of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones and the cuneiform bones.
  • Injuries of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement.
  • Mechanism of injury-injuries occur mostly because of high energy injuries like forced hyper flexion of ankle in road traffic accident.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lisfranc injuries disrupt the tarsometatarsal joints and often require weight-bearing views for diagnosis due to subtle diastasis.
  • Surgical fixation is critical to prevent chronic midfoot collapse and osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with idiopathic congenital clubfoot. The orthopaedic surgeon plans serial manipulation and casting using the Ponseti method. In the first cast, which component of the deformity should be corrected?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Cavus is corrected first by supinating the forefoot and dorsiflexing the 1st metatarsal, realigning the medial column and reducing the high-arched appearance characteristic of clubfoot.

PONSETI METHOD:

  • Ponseti method of choice now with a success rate of >95%. This procedure consists of manipulating the foot for 1-3 minutes into corrected position, followed by holding the correction in an above knee cast (applied with knees flexed to 90°).
  • After 7 days, cast is removed, foot re-manipulated, and recasted for another week in successively more corrected position. Usually, 5 to 7 casts are sufficient and deformity gets corrected.
  • The order of correction is very important. It can be remembered by the pneumonic 'CAVE'. Cavus is corrected in the 1st cast by supinating the forefoot and dorsiflexing the 1st metatarsal.
  • Pronation (Option B) must be avoided throughout, as pronation worsens cavus and hinders correction.
  • Adduction (Option C) and varus are then corrected simultaneously in the subsequent casts by abducting the forefoot in supination with counter pressure being applied at talar head.
  • Lastly, equinus (Option D) is corrected, by dorsiflexing the fully abducted foot.
  • In case dorsiflexion is difficult beyond neutral then a percutaneous tenotomy of Tendo Achilles is done to achieve adequate dorsiflexion.

questions.text: A child is born with CTEV (Congenital Talipes Equinus Varus). All of the following can be the causes except
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Poliomyelitis causes a paralytic (acquired) clubfoot later in life due to muscle imbalance, not a primary deformity present at birth.
  • Distinguishing between primary and secondary (acquired) clubfoot etiologies is vital for selecting the appropriate timing and method of treatment (Ponseti casting versus surgical correction).
  • Primary (Congenital clubfoot): Cases where clubfoot may be present since birth include:
    • Idiopathic (most common type) (Option C)
    • Neurogenic-Spina bifida (Option B)
    • Dysplastic-Arthrogryposis multiplex congenital (AMC). (Option D)
  • Secondary (Acquired clubfoot): In some diseases a muscle imbalance may result, causing contracture of the posteromedial foot structures leading to a secondary CTEV anytime during life.
    • Paralytic (Poliomyelitis)
    • Post-traumatic-contracted scar on posteromedial aspect
    • Post infective.
    • Spastic (Cerebral palsy).

Key Takeaways:

  • Primary congenital CTEV arises idiopathically or secondary to neurogenic/dysplastic disorders present at birth.
  • Acquired (paralytic) clubfoot, such as that from poliomyelitis, is managed differently and occurs after infancy.

questions.text: A patient undergoes serial casting for the foot abnormalities shown in Figure A and achieves excellent correction. Unfortunately, the patient returns at 22 months of age with a recurrence which will require repeat casting and posteromedial releases. What is/are the risk factor(s) for recurrence in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Noncompliance with foot abduction orthosis (FAO) and parental education level of high school or below are risk factors for recurrence after correction of idiopathic clubfoot using the Ponseti method.
  • The Ponsetti method of serial manipulation and casting is >90% successful in correcting clubfoot and preventing the need for surgical releases other than Achilles tenotomy. After serial casting and tenotomy, the patient is fitted for a foot abduction orthosis (FAO) which is worn for 23 hours per day for the first few months after casting and then nightly until around age 4 year.
  • Compliance with FAO usage is the most important factor in preventing clubfoot recurrence and this is influenced by the parent's education level.

choices.text: Tried correcting equinus before heel varus
Used below knee casts instead of above knee casts

questions.text: A 3-month-old patient with clubfoot who you've been treating with the Ponseti Method has returned to your clinic. On examination, the foot appears as it does in Figure A. What treatment error has been made?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Rocker bottom foot deformity occurs when equinus is corrected before heel varus and forefoot pronation.
  • Congenital clubfoot, or talipes equinovarus, consists of four main parts: midfoot cavus, metatarsus adductus, varus hindfoot, and equinus contracture. The goal of manipulation is to rotate the foot around a fixed talus. This must be done in the order described by Ponseti.
  • The mnemonic C-A-V-E is an easy method to remember the order of treatment (Cavus, metatarus Adductus, Varus, Equinus). If equinus is addressed before the cavus and varus hindfoot, dorsiflexion occurs through the midfoot instead of treating the hindfoot equinus, thus creating a rockerbottom foot.

Explanation of Other Options:

Under correction of foot pronation (Option A) can leave residual cavus deformity by failing to fully supinate the forefoot and elevate the 1st metatarsal.

Over corrected metatarsus adductus (Option B) results in forefoot abduction deformity, but would not produce a rocker-bottom midfoot collapse.

Used below knee casts instead of above knee casts (Option D) insufficient immobilization; Ponseti casts must encompass the knee (flexed at 90°) to maintain supination and control rotation.

questions.text: Which is not true about CTEV shoe?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • CTEV shoes feature a straight inner border, not an outer one, to prevent the foot from drifting medially and maintain corrected alignment.

CTEV shoes:

  • These are the modified shoes which are used only when the child starts walking. (Option B)
  • The special modifications made in these kinds of shoes are:
    1. Straight inner border in order to prevent the inward movement of the foot.
    2. Outer border of the shoe raised in order to prevent foot inversion. (Option D)
    3. Designed without a heel to avoid reintroducing equinus. (Option C)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child who underwent Ponseti casting for idiopathic clubfoot presents with a rigid, convex sole ("rocker-bottom") deformity of the foot. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Excessive dorsiflexion of the midfoot (equinus correction) before adequately addressing cavus and hindfoot varus in Ponseti casting causes midtarsal "break", producing a convex plantar surface.
  • Rocker bottom foot can occur after congenital vertical talus or improper treatment in CTEV and can be associated with syndromic conditions like Arthrogryposis, Neurofibromatosis, Trisomy 13-15 and 18, Spina bifida and Prune Belly syndrome.
  • Recognition of this error is essential, as management may require re-casting in the correct sequence (Cavus → Adduction/Varus → Equinus) or surgical realignment for optimal foot architecture.

Explanation of Other Options:

Malunited fracture of the calcaneum (Option A) leads to hindfoot varus/valgus and altered heel height, not midfoot convexity.

Neural tube defect (Option B) associated with congenital vertical talus and neuropathic arthropathy but not the typical post-Ponseti rocker-bottom deformity.

Horizontal talus (Option C) describes congenital vertical talus seen at birth; this patient's deformity is iatrogenic post-treatment.

Key Takeaways:

  • Avoid premature equinus correction in the Ponseti sequence to prevent midfoot collapse and rocker-bottom deformity.
